text: The food is awesome, but the customer service is not that great. I guess it is their culture. If you are looking for good authentic Taiwanese food, this is the place to go to, but don't expect a highly attentive staff to serve you. I've been to the other Taiwanese restaurants in Chinatown, but so far, this deli has better customer service than those ones. At least the staff here smiles at you, for me that's friendly enough.
Taiwanese food in las Vegas... This place is like eating in my grandma's house in Taiwan... Nostalgia and authenticity make this place worth visiting!

Worse service ever!! The waitress sent the wrong food and drinks even we had been waiting for 2 hrs for our order. After all the long waiting, of course we had to wait for the check, wait to pay, the waitress told us we supposedly to pay 18% of tips! WTF! Won't visit this restaurant ever again!

Went because they are say they are from taiwan and store was recommended. Ok food and terrible service. 11:15 in the morning and they are "out of food". The lady was actually yelling at and insulting my wife over the counter.  

They actually did have food, and lots of it, they just didn't feel like serving what they had. At lunchtime. The only thing they wanted to serve was insults and bad attitude.

Go elsewhere if you want food without the tude. Or I guess just food in the first place.

Perhaps one of the best experience I've had ever in a environment of just total friendly people and excellent service period with the most delectable and unusual breakfast items I've ever had I enjoyed every single thing that I was provided and would recommend this to anybody to try

The food is really good but the service is terrible. We waited for a long time and when we tried to get the menu by ourself, the service lady yelled at us. It is the first time that I have such experience. If you really want the food, just order take out. This is my sincere advice.

Browsed Yelp for places that serves breakfast at 8am other than fast food and we came here.  Authentic Taiwanese food with a good variety.  All we ordered tasted good; beef noodles, radish cake, you tiao and Xiao Long Bao.  The staff are also very friendly and welcoming!  Recommended when you have Chinese food crave!

Lunch today was wonderful. Hospitality was the greatest. Very helpful that English was spoken, sometimes that does make ordering difficult at other locations. Food was primarily steamed, not fried in grease. I'm liking that a lot! We'll be back.

I was really craving for Chinese breakfast and would really want to find somewhere with soy milk and you tiao.  The only place I can find thru Yelp is Yi Mei.  However, 3.5 stars makes me skeptical if I should check out this place.  I was really lucky to give it a try! I love the you tiao wrapped in egg and the beef noodle is yummy too! Everything is great, thou service can be improved...

With our schedules often in conflict, my mom and I rarely get to eat meals together. Some planets aligned, call it fate, whatever. We finally had the opportunity to have a late Saturday lunch together, courtesy of this Taiwanese deli. Initially, we were going off of her dim sum craving, but decided to try something different. *cue my devious plan to suggest one of my many Yelp bookmarks*

After browsing the menu for a few minutes, we decided on the pork chop rice and the three cup chicken rice. Didn't take very long to get our food and man, their portions are HUGE. One of our entrees could've fed two or three people, so you should either come famished or bring a friend! We ended up splitting the crispy fried pork chop and taking the other entree home. Both dishes had their respective meats, some steamed or blanched vegetables, a large helping of rice, and a soy sauce egg. Mmm, did that meal hit the spot or what?

Service was courteous and friendly, but you may have to get your own napkins and water. If you're afraid of language barriers, it turns out some of them speak English, so no fear! My mom and I speak a lesser known dialect, but we managed with the Mandarin we knew. Also, you're probably better off bringing cash to pay the bill, but most Asian establishments are like that.

Definitely want to try their other offerings, especially their breakfast items and noodle soups.

This place is close to the strip and has amazing Taiwanese breakfast. 

They serve fresh unsweetened soy milk, and yummy rice ball. One would think deep-fried Chinese donuts would be good, right? But nope, they may be fried in old oil. Here, they have fresh oil! The deep-fried donuts are crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. 

Next time I am in Vegas, I will most def swing by for breakfast. 

Plus, for 2 people, my bill came out to be less than $12.

The service is good, speed is good, food is delish. Ordered: stinky tofu, quite good but a little pricy- wonton in hot chili oil, good but again expensive, chicken leg rice, good fair price.fan twan: good $3 OVERALL GOOD FOOD BUT A LITTLE ON THE EXPENSIVE SIDE also on weekends Theresa bunch of people so sometimes you'll have to wait for a seat.
The food is generally ok. But the service is very very bad. Waiter/waitress always complain in front of customers

It's hard to find some good Taiwanese food in Las Vegas. I come here often with my parents because they miss eating food from their homeland. The food is usually bland, but sometimes it's okay. I guess it depends on the chef. The oyster omelet is fairly bland, even with the sauce on top. Most of the time the oysters are only half cooked. The stinky tofu is nothing special. It just tastes like fried tofu. The spicy beef soup and the pork chop rice are the only things I like to get from there because everything else is bland or super bland.

This is a traditional Taiwanese deli. Some of the food only come with small portion. I had  a baked beef pocket bread and a spicy cucumber for lunch.  It was a quick lunch and the price is good and the service was bad.

It's not recommend for whole family to dine in. But it's ok for a quick meal.

Usually I am okay with the service of this restaurant. But came in to buy to go but they are taking a tour bus group. When I walked in, no one is asking to help you and one person came over and ask me "what are you doing here and said we are closed." Really bad service!

Nice authentic food with fast service. We had rice milk, soy milk, rice roll, fish ball soup and wrapped rice dumpling. They all tasted good and had great portion. But this place is a little crowed and busy, maybe due to holiday season.
As a previous reviewer mentioned they do seem to add 15% tip by default no matter dine in or take out, which is uncommon for small groups below 6 people. I feel bad and sad about this "clever" trick, so minus one star.

I'd like to come here for breakfast once in a while. I speak fluently in Chinese, so there wouldn't be any language barrier. The service used to be ok, since the owner who is a really nice Taiwanese lady served me couple time.
However, this time when I went there was HORRIBLE! The first second I walked into the restaurant, there was another Taiwanese elderly lady standing behind the cashier. She was staring at me without any welcoming smile when I was walking to her. When I was standing right in front of her, she didn't greet with me and kinda waiting for me to greet with her. And she gave me a really irritating face! Then she lift up her chin a little bit and blinked in the most annoying way I've ever seen. Ok, I ignored that. Then I told her what I wanted to order for to-go. Then, there's another young male customer came to the cashier and asked for a check. She gave him a very bright smile and called him "handsome boy" in Chinese and finished his transaction before me. Really! The guy came after me!!!!! 
Ok, I ignored that too. When she handled me my food, she said "shiiiit!" In English. She said it really loud. I didn't really know if she was saying that to me or for something else, but it's still rude to curse in front of a customer.
She is definitely the rudest and the most miserable person I've ever met in my entire life. I didn't do anything or showed any disrespect to her from the very beginning to the end. I even said "thank you" after all of this.
Btw, last time me and my bf were there for breakfast, they undercooked the wonton. And it smelled wired. 
I will NEVER put my feet in this restaurant, and I don't recommend this place to any of you. If you love your life, stay away from this place!!!!

Best Taiwanese food I have ever had across the U.S. Speaking of a man (and a decent cook) born and raised in Taiwan and has been living in the U.S. for eight years. Hell yeah. 

Definitely try the beef noodle soup, sticky rice ball, and fried pork chop rice dish. You'd regret if you don't.

Mmmmmmm.  Traditional Taiwanese breakfast in Vegas.  Good food for the price.  Portion is decent, and the dining area is clean and neat.  Huge parking lot, and plenty of parking.  Service is okay.  Well worth to stop by if you are around the hood and are willing to try something else other than ordinary American breakfast in Vegas.

They have very interesting menu items that I have not seen in Hawaii so had to try.

First off was Duck Tongue, which was the best dish we had.  Had that 5 spice taste but was very mild, which I liked.  It was served cold , tender meat but watch out for the cartilage.  Next was the Stinky Fried Tofu.   It was OK and it does smell like an old sock.  Next "Spicy" Beef Noodle, I put the quotes because it was not spicy at all.  Noodles had a nice chew to it, nice beefy flavor from the soup,  big chunks of beef and tendon.  Overall it was a nice dish but wanted it SPICY.  Lastly we had the Shiao Long Bao.  First time eating it so have no reference point.  It's OK, wish the dipping sauce had a little more vinegar to it.

Not sure if our next Vegas trip we'll go here again.  If we did I'd definitely order the duck tongue again and probably try other item.

I came to Las Vegas for the CES 2013! This is the 4th year we are here! 5 star hotel buffets are always the best choice for us in the past 3 years! We went to something different this year and they are the best experience in my whole life! My two friends live in Taiwan and they went to this restaurant with me three times during the CES show! We order the lunch box two times! You can tell how much we love this restaurant! I am the restaurant owner in NY! I do know if you go to one restaurant and you see the owner there all the time! You can feel release and sure that you will get the best food just like cook from the owner's home kitchen! The meal is for the family members not just customer! I am sure I will fly to Vegas just for the food in Taiwan deli again this year!

Great chinese food.  They got a little bit of everything.  I come here mainly for the Chinese Breakfast.  Like Chinese Donut, great onion pancake, beef wraps, rice wraps, etc.  The beef noodle soup is also really good.  Got to check it out.

Had brunch there.  Looks very rundown but food is good.  Had xiao long bao, beef noodles and tofu fa.  Its nothing overly exciting but it was good.  It wa snice to have something diff from what the strip offers.

The worst!!! My husband went to pick up some breakfast today along with some soy milk and soy peanut milk. When he return home, we realized both soy milk and soy peanut milk were spoiled. I called the restaurant and the lady over the phone insisted that it was impossible that the drinks were spoiled!! Never going back there again!!!
Be aware! They charge you tips! We only had 3 adult and 1 infant, never got charge tips for only 3 people eating! Also the rice noodle and stinky tofu was really bad! Never come here again!

Giving this restaurant 1 star for the 4 stars that used to be and the negative 3 that is now.
This been our favorite whenever we wanted a good bowl of Taiwanese style noodle soup. Something had happened, went there on 6-2-13 for lunch at 11:30am. The place was packed as usual. The waitress twice tried to put 3 of  us at a table that was barely big enough for 2. She was displeased when I refused and told her that we did not mind waiting.
I ordered beef noodle soup WITHOUT  green onion (I cannot eat it), of course it came with green onion. After scooped out most of it, found the beef was tough and the broth was salty. Ate less than half of my bowl, my first time of not finishing my food here.
As a lover of family run and hole in wall type of restaurants, never set high expectation for great service, but got to be at an acceptable level. This place always has spotty service, but was never this bad.
The place was almost empty when we left (12:30pm), very unusual for this place on a Sunday noon. May be other patrons also voted with their feet and went somewhere else. We sure will try out the other Taiwanese restaurant in the same shopping center.
Great place for lunch. Yet to try breakfast. Lovely owners, didn't charge extra for a new melon tea when I split it open all over the table.
...Food does not taste good, wait for a long time, I dont  want back again...
The next time (and every time) I'm in Vegas, I will be back here for the steamed vegetable buns. Amazingly good!

I love their authentic Taiwanese food! I had the traditional Taiwanese style breakfast, Taiwanese pork chop rice, beef noodle soup, Pan fried dumplings, green onion pan cakes, etc. Everything we had was delicious, and the price is reasonable. This place is packed in the morning, so please be a little patient when they are doing their best to be fast. You can come after 9am if you have time, and usually they are not that busy after 9am. You may get a chance to chat with them when they are not busy. :D After all, the food is worth waiting! The owners, waitress and waiters are very friendly. The calligraphy and paintings hanging in the room are very fine, and I like the fish in the thank. They look like my pet fish when I was a kid. I feel like home here.

We love the foods here. The owner is also very friendly. We enjoy Taiwanese food, especially breakfast.  We sometimes order to go and bring them back to hotel, share with friends and families.  They are all appreciated and enjoy.

So far been to Vegas twice and visited Yi Mei three times for breakfast! It's rare to see a place that serves Taiwanese breakfast at 7:00AM everyday throughout the week... as least not many places like that on the east coast. In terms of quality, the FOOD IS GREAT! It also has a great variety of Taiwanese items. My favorite are there rice rolls. And yes, plural, because there are FIVE different kind of rice rolls! Yi Mei and Champion Rice Rolls are the best! Everything we tried were pretty good... steam pork & veg bun, sweet bean curd, radish bun, Taiwanese meat ball, and leek dumplings. We had a variety of steam buns to go... and all of them were great! Pork and Mushroom and Vegetarian are must tries! Really like how they had sweet cold soil milk readily available - taste great!

Didn't try any of the non-breakfast stuff probably because the breakfast were sooo good, but I'm sure the other items are just as excellent. In general, the price is a little on the high side for Taiwanese food, but it's worth it! Really would like to try the pork chop rice next time.

The food here is very mediocre for breakfast. It wasn't very authentic tasting at all. The shao bin was really really dry and the you tiao was way too crispy. The Taiwanese sausage dish we got was really greasy and felt/tasted like they kept it outside for over a day already. The food over all was not TERRIBLE but I would go somewhere else next time if I have a choice.

They overcharge big time for the oyster omelette and skimped on the ingredient. I counted two partial slivers of very stale oysters, which left a really bad taste at $8-9 a dish. I also ordered a fried chicken rice plate, which was probably the most dry, flavorless fried chicken steak I've ever had.

I am so happy found this place!  Great food - I have not had something that I would not have again.  Some of my favorite (very traditional):
--Sweet soy bean milk (you need to add sugar to it yourself)
--Chinese donut
--Man-Tou (white steamed buns - no filling)

I agree with the other reviewer - do not expect good service.  Great food though - so yes, I am a fan!

Their spicy beef/tendon noodle soup is the most authentic Taiwanese food I've ever had.....the quality and flavor are consistently good every time, the portion and price are good as well....I've never tried other items in the menu because this is their signature dish in my opinion :)

I come here for the Spicy Beef Noodle Soup. It's flavor is fairly close to a famous place that has been around for ages in Ximen, Taipei.  Visually, the soup looks thin, but all the flavor is there.  There are veggies (baby bok choy) and healthy chunks of flavorful meat and tendon in the bowl. I usually get it without the shredded pickles, since I'm not a fan of pickles.

All the other food that I've tried is ok to good.  But if I'm coming here, it's for that Spicy Beef Noodle Soup.

On a recent trip to Las Vegas, we liked this place very much that we ate here TWICE... for breakfast and for lunch.  Had Chinese Donut+Soy bean milk...   love this & while eating this, it brought back pleasant nostalgic memories.  Beef roll is great.  The spicy beef & tendon noodle soup is the best I've had... loved the pickled vegetables, beef broth is wonderful & noodle texture is just right. 

This place is a "mom-pop" type of eatery so adjust your expectation level on service when they get very busy & most important of all - do not take it personally.  If you are a international foodie, you should know this.  :)
Very good food and owner is very friendly. She came talked to us like she knew us for long times.  Too bad we are only here for vacation, otherwise I would be their loyal costumer.

I love their spicy beef and tendon noodle soup. It comes in this bowl that looks small in circumference but is deep, so it's a lot of food. The noodles are cooked just right, beef could be a bit softer, but there's very little fat in it, and the broth is hot and spicy. There's only a few places I go in town to get my beef noodle fix, and this is on the top of my list. If you don't speak Mandarin or look Chinese, I find that they tend to make the soup less spicy because they don't think you can handle it, so ask the waitress to make the soup super spicy.

They have a wide variety of Taiwanese dishes, ranging from breakfast to lunch items. I haven't tried their breakfast, so I can't comment on it. But they do have the typical Taiwanese appetizers and dishes, such as pig's ear, oyster pancake, and pork chop rice. The only dish I'm not a fan of is the noodles with the spicy peanut sauce, only because it tastes like peanut butter and chili garlic sauce mixed together. 

Service is on the lackluster side, they like to assume that if you look Chinese, you must be able to speak Mandarin and nothing else (like Cantonese). If you want water, you have to go to the water dispenser to get some. There's usually only one waitress working, so if you don't want to wait to pay for your bill, it's better to just go up to the register and do it. Also, there's a minimum $10 order if you're using a debit or credit card. 

Overall, Yi Mei has some great Taiwanese food but their service could use some improvement.

We tried the beef roll, xiao long bao, and the green onion pancake. The beef roll wasn't as meaty as I expected, and the wrap was more tortilla-like instead of crisp and flaky on the outside. The xiao long bao were fresh off the steamer and pretty good. The green onion pancake was a bit thick for me and didn't have much green onion.

This is Taiwanese breakfast place and it is great for the price and value. My kids love their Chinese steamed mini pork bun Chinese called ????If you are passing by Las Vegas and looking for Chinese breakfast place this is the place to go! They also sell other Chinese goodies like duck tongs and wings! Yum yum! Everything is home made!!!

AMAZING FOOD!!! 

The most authentic Taiwanese food I have had since visiting Taiwan! 

Breakfast and lunch specialties that can't be found anywhere else in Vegas! 

My mother-in-law is from Taiwan and this is her favorite restaurant when she comes into town. 

The spicy beef noodle soup is a must have when you come here! The portions are large so I usually share with my wife. Everything is made fresh to order, and they have a huge selections of dishes. 

Some of our other favorites include:
spicy wanton soup
fried onion pancake
turnip cake with a fried egg on top (Luo Buo Gao)
Pork and mushroom steamed buns
Curry meat pies
Sun cakes
Soy bean milk (made fresh daily)
rice roll (fan tuan)
twisted cruller (you tiao)
Baked wheat cake (shao bing)
Fried pot stickers
And several more that I can't remember right now

A MUST TRY FOR ANY ASIAN FOOD LOVER!!!

i went here to eat a good Chinese Breakfast. 

i've been to the one in California and hoped that it was the same quality and it was to my surprise!

i ordered:
hot soy milk (very good made from scratch, add ur own sugar)
chinese donut (wasn't stale)
rice burrito (good amount of filling)
egg pancake ( big portion but too oily)

all it was surprisingly good, because vegas isn't known for good asian cuisine. next time i'm going to get the special

for 3.99
soymilk, chinese donut and a baked beef/pork sanwich

where else can you get a wholesome breakfast for that price! 

the service was typical asian style, no particular waitress, just grab whoever has a apron on for attention :) 

BTW BREAKFAST ENDS AT 11:30AM!

they serve lunch and dinner also, from what i saw it was very traditional taiwan food ei:dumplings,beef noodle soup,etc.

I might come back if i ever feel like eating my favorite again.  

The owner of this restaurant is the same one from Champion on Spring Mountain Rd.  It's in the same mall of the old SF supermarket.  

Please don't let the their service discourage you from visiting this place again.  This is how their service works.  When you get there, they don't really seat you, you just find a spot to sit, get your own water from the dispenser and grab your own utensils for food.  You can either go up to the counter to get their menu or you can wait for them.  Either way.  Their service isn't the best but that's how they roll.

I'm only giving this place 2 stars because I've read the review from someone else about this place and he said that they didn't have some of the items on the menu.  So I decided to wait a few days afterwards to go.  But, the items that were unavailable from the previous review, was still UNAVAILABLE.  This makes me wonder, if they even have the man power to run a business like this.  Why did they advertise Taiwanses deli when they don't have soy drinks? Why they don't have shao lung bao? Waitress said to me that since they are so busy, the chef is unable to make the shao lung bao.  (Oh really?  Do you want the business from me? Seriuosly?  No? I guess not!)  

It just doesn't make sense to me why they don't hire more people to help outside and inside of the kitchen?  Why don't they better prepare themselves? They've been in business for a while week already and not to mention, they only moved over from their previous business, so they have experience already.  

I then suddenly remember how the sluggish atmosphere is like from the old champion restaurant.  It's the exact same thing.  They probably want to improve business but don't really know how to handle a busy business within their management.  

I want to review on their dam dam mein.  It used to taste really good at the old location, and i expected it to be the same. But it didnt' taste the same.  Not only did they not have the appropriate  that they were supposed to serve , the peanut sauce was really bland.    They didn't have soy that i wanted to drink, they didn't have the siu lung bao, that i wanted.  I ordered my normal favorite and it turned out horrible.  I also ordered the Beef noodle which didn't taste great either.  

Over all, i was really disappointed in their management.  I hope their services will improve in the future.  I will not be back there for a while.

Sweet potato cake is so good!!
Egg pancake is good too!!
Most of the stuff is great here!!

It's a Taiwanese restaurant, Cali is like that wit the bad service.  Just come for the food and forget about the service.  They don't speak/understand English that well, so don't get disappointed.  They prefer you to let them know when you're ready to order.  

I'm tossed between the Noodle Pot restaurant & this place for the spicy beef stew.  The flavorings are really different.  One feels like its has more flavor (Noodle pot) but I get so thirsty afterwards.  This Yi Mei feels like it can add a little bit more seasoning but the portion size & noodles are more than the Noodle pot.  Btw, Noodle Pot only takes CASH but Yi Mei accepts credit cards.  They're both Good but I wish they taste more like Monterey Park.  I switch off between them depending which one is the closes at that moment.

I went there with my college buddies and I have to say the food was awesome! It was the first time I had a Taiwanese breakfast which included beef rolls, sweet soymilk and egg pancake. The egg pancake was definitely my favorite. The owner even gave us some free sweet fried bread to go. I am definitely coming back the next time I am in town.

Maybe it's Las Vegas and no expectation should be given to the Chinese food, but this place is really nothing more than normal as to the food quality. The only benefit you may get is the opportunity to have some traditional Chinese breakfast. They have a lot of choices, mainly from Taiwan and Tianjin. The staff were extremely inefficient and inattentive. We complained a few times about the speed of getting our food, but nobody cared and a boy waiter even coldly said "talk to whoever took your order" (although he clearly knew who took our order, he even did not tell that waitress who kept staying behind the counter when walked by). One star given to the choice of food, but would strongly advise this restaurant to get improved.
This place definitely satisfied my cravings for Chinese food. The food was prepared really quick. It's a good place to grab and go while road tripping!
Awesome TW breakfast! also love their beef noodle soup!

Food is really good but have to wait a while for it come out. Everything is fresh so as long as you don't mind waiting for your food you will have a good time. Staff are friendly but don't speak much English. Go for the experience and don't be in a rush.

We went to this restaurant for the soup dumplings on Sunday morning at around 10, and they said they would not make them. Next morning we returned very early at 7:30 in hopes they would make them and they refused yet again. If the soup dumplings are on your menu, they should actually be available. Very irritated.

I went Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli. So when i was there i ordered Taiwanese Gua Bao "Braised Pork Slice in a steamed bun". i waited for my food it has been 20 minutes. I thought that maybe there making it really nice and yummy. After waiting like a YEAR.........

IT FINALLY CAME!!! Then when i saw it. It had cling wrap all over it. And you can tell it was it microwaved. YUCK! Never coming back EVER!!! XP

I was so excited to spot this place on my trip in Vegas and entered hoping for some authentic Taiwanese breakfast. The food was cheap and the servers very polite. I had a fantuan with a bowl of rice drink (mijian). The portions were rather small and the taste underwhelming.

Super delicious find in Vegas! I love a good Taiwanese breakfast + this was perfectly satisfying. The staff is super nice + helpful. Now the food:
- soybean milk: perfect, hit the spot!
- Chinese donut: fresh, but really oily, though I ate most of it so I guess it wasn't that bad :) I would order it again.
- Beef roll: the most disappointing thing we ordered. Not like the beef rolls I've had before. It looks really tasty but it didn't taste like anything. I would not get this again. I'd try the beef pocket instead. I saw other people eating that + it looked delicious.
- salted rice roll: my favorite thing + I don't know why it's not more common, like onigiri...anyways perfect rice to meat floss to Chinese donuts proportions.  I could eat this every day.
- Shanghai dumplings: really tasty but the skins were all broken so there was no soup, but still really tasty.

There service is excellent and food is really good quality.really athletic Chinese breakfast.good affordable price as well..much more better than the mama's kitchen across the street..high recommended!

It was amazing Taiwan breakfast, bet in Vegas by far. Their radish cake was unlike any dim sum place in Vegas. The owners are nice and the service was good. Im from Taiwan and the breakfast here is as good as some places back home.

This place used to be amazing, but now, it had gone somewhat downhill. I think the chef might have changed so now everything is just a little bit off. The wait staff are very slow and unprofessional, but tolerable in the past because there are so few authentic Chinese breakfast places. Waitress forgetting orders, being rude, making excuses are common. 

If you are looking for Chinese breakfast, and do not have a lot of time and/or something to do while waiting, I'd suggest ordering take out instead. They do accept credit cards, min $10 order.
I love love their mochi, peanut, black sesame and red bean, all delicious! They make it in house. Friendly people.

Seasoned duck necks are ideal appetizer. Salty and sweet soy bean milk are warm and suitable to the cold weather. The XIAOLONG bun is my favorite even tho the chef is from TAIWAN. Never miss The TAIWAN Sausage! No ideas on the breakfast or brunch? Come here!

Loved this place for their authenticity, at a fair price.  Will definitely be back.

Dragonball - Aesthetically poor, but I enjoyed the taste.

Pork chop rice - Very good, especially the generous servings of the minced pork.  Taste of the inced pork is very authentic.  Quality of the rice was good - very important!!

Beef noodle soup (plain broth) - Very flavorful, delicious.

Stinky tofu - avoid.  More like plain fried tofu.

Oyster Omelette - Something wasn't right about this dish, maybe they used the wrong starch?  Taste was okay.

Service was above average for a Chinese restaurant.  Price was very fair.  Can't wait to try everything.
We like the egg cake and beef roll. There are more dishes to try. They offer authentic Taiwanese food. Prices are very affordable. The fish ball is also good. Service is ok.

I went here with my friend for lunch. We had both just went to Taiwan and were very excited to remember the great food we experienced there. Although we did eat and leave full, we felt that the food wasn't the same. Some of the ingredients did not seem high quality. The sauces weren't as flavorful, either. Is there any good, flavorful, authentic Taiwanese food in Vegas?

So... since my last review I believe they moved to a bigger location. It was nearly empty when I came back this month. The food seemed to be ok, and not as good as I remembered. The kicker is when I found a strand of hair in my xiao long bao. I was completely turned off after that. I didn't tell my waiter because he seemed like a nice guy, but it's unappetizing to find things like that especially for breakfast when you're barely awake. Not sure if I will return.

I always have a soft spot for Taiwanese breakfast. Some soybean milk and fan tuan are the best way to start a day. It is rather hard for me to not enjoy them unless they are really badly prepared. (something I have yet to experience)

Yi Mei is one of the few off the strip places that open super early. There were no wait when I arrived before 9 but the restaurant was quickly filled to capacity an hour later.

I think 3.5 stars is a fairly accurate rating for Yi Mei. It is much better than 3 but not quite 4 stars yet. Soybean milk and fan tuan (rice roll) were nicely done. The leek filling pancake was a bit too hard and too oily. Steamed Pork and Vegetable Bun
was generous in portion and quite tasty. Taiwan Style Rice Wrapped was just average.

I was quite happy with the breakfast at Yi Mei. Pretty sure I will return next time and try out more of their other dishes.
Best Taiwanese breakfast place in Vegas. We tried about 10 different dishes and they are all good. Service is subpar but no complaint about the food ! Very authentic!

After 6 days of road trip with Continental and American breakfast, This place is like a breath of fresh air! The beef noodle soup is bit spicy, noodle is too soft for my taste. But everything else is right on. Normally, I would give it a 3 star but judging from the circumstance and it's Vegas, I gave it a 4.
This is an okay representation of Taiwan street food. The owners are very nice. The food is all right, nothing comparable to something you can find in LA.

The best beef noodles outside of Taiwan and even better than some of the average beef noodle joints on the island. The nut milks and morning breakfast options are also amazing. Would happily make a trip out to Vegas just for the food here! Simply delicious and worth the journey!

One of my favorite Chinese restaurants!! I live in New York, but go to Vegas every year or so and this is my first stop! The owners are so sweet and nice to me, and remember me and my family everytime we go. The food reminds me of Taiwan, and there's definitely no Chinese food in New York like this. I'm from LA near monterey park and this is still my favorite spot!

One of the very few asian breakfast places in town.

Serving a variety of items of not only breakfast, but lunch and other in-store made items as well. 

Things to try are their fresh hot soy milk and yao tiao (chinese... donut?). Two chinese staples for breakfast. Other things are like oyster omelettes, fan tuan (taiwanese style rice ball with pork sung - salty), etc. 

As said before, not only breakfast, but lunch items as well. my favorite is their spicy beef noodle soup (niao rou mian). though not as spicy as i wanted, but still pretty good. HUGE portion (beware!) so if you are a small eater, may consider sharing with another !
Very good for brunch. Both the quality and quantity are excellent and it is not pricy at all.

Came here craving beef noodle soup so we ordered that, along with a few other stuff like taiwanese minced pork over rice, steamed xiao lung bao, squid paste soup?, beef roll, soy bean milk, spiced tofu with pork ears, and a fried sesame bread from the warmer. I only tried a few of the items and thought they were okay but I did enjoy the beef noodle soup. The broth was a little salty but it was very flavorful. This will be my "go to" spot for authentic taiwanese beef noodle soup.

PS, since we came here before Chinese New Year, we saw a lot of authentic gifts and pastries to give as gifts to the relatives and to place inside the home for luck and such. They had huge steamed buns, red fish for luck and buns for b-day folks (sau bao). Very interesting sight to see!

I was craving Taiwanese bfast Friday morning and thankfully found Yei Mei!
I guess I shouldn't be too surprised, since it is located in Chinatown. =)

We ordered...
Sweet soy milk
Salty soy milk 
Chinese donuts (youtiao) 
Salty rice rolls -(fan tuan)

I was simply sipping my soy milk and barely added any sugar. 
Dipped the youtiao in and yummmmm .. not too greasy. :)
Didn't get to finish it because of the fan taun of doom!!!
It's huge -- I barely finished half and was not hungry till dinner (and even then..barely hungry). If you ever find yourself lost in the wilderness, bring a fan tuan and live for days. 

I didn't try the salty soy  milk (who orders that for bfast??? .. Tim does, that's who...must be a HK thing.. =P .. I eyed him suspiciously throughout the meal). 

Total was around $16... and we didn't finish the food. Service is very good and it's really clean in here. Loved that everyone spoke Chinese but don't fret, they do have an English menu. They also sell baked goods on the side..

This place is great for the most part. There are some days where the food is inconsistant and just terrible, but out of all the times I've been here, it's usually pretty good. I LOVE the stinky tofu here. It's hard to find good stinky tofu, but this place is my number 1 spot for stinky tofu. They also make their soy milk from scratch! Yum! Also order the beef stew noodle. This item if gone on the right day is delicious. But when the soup is new, the the soup isn't as flavorful but still ok.

The service? When coming here, forget about the service. You don't get service. Service here is terrible. The servers have no desire to "work it" and make there tips here. Not only do you serve yourself water, but the after dropping off the food, it's rare for you to see another server for a while. 

The atmosphere of this place is crappy. Its a small dinky place with only a few tables, and it feels cramped and crowded. 

Only reason this gets a four star is because of the food. I love Food, and can careless about the service or the atmosphere.
It's super awesome.  We were visiting Vegas with the parents for Thanksgiving and went there three days in a row!   Five stars for the salty soy milk, beef sandwich and beef noodle soup.

We went there on a Wednesday morning in a hurry. There was a lot of people in the restaurant. I think they were from a vacation tour. I was not very happy to see that they cater to large groups like that, because the limited time we have. 

It took awhile before we ordered, but the food came out quick. All the items we ordered were pre-made anyway. We ordered 2 hot soy milk, 2 youtiao(fried dough), 1 shaobing( baked sesame cake). The food was pretty good. I was disappointed that they don't offer the special anymore though.

I gotta bump up the rating to one more star for an improvement in the juicy dumplings (xiao long bao) and potstickers (guo tie).

We went for a lazy Sunday morning breakfast at Yi Mei.  We mainly went for noodles, but we didn't know that noodle dishes are not available until lunch time.  It definitely worked out because the server recommended the pot stickers.

1.  Pot Stickers - Juicy lil' baby morsels of meat and add in the crispy fried skin
2.  Juicy Pork Dumplings - improvement!  the meat wasn't as salty.  the skin was thinner, which is better in my mind.  juicier but still not as juicy as din tai fung caliber

Conclusion:  up 1 star for improvement and juicy and flavor factors!

SUPER 5 stars.  Their breakfast here is awesome! Way way better than Irvine's 4 Seas restaurant.  We came here to check out their Taiwanese breakfast and we are glad we came here.  Super friendly customer service especially, Mr.Chow.  He was our waiter and gave us a great impression of this place.  We ordered so much and it was super delicious.  And we even order beef noodles soup and soooo good!! Super yummmy!! Please go to their place and try their food.  They are open from 6am-3pm.  So go their early.  You will not regret it!

I love all Taiwanese food, but especially taiwanese breakfast, so I was super psyched to find this place.  Here's what we ordered:

oyster pancake - bleh bleh bleh.  the sauce was was REALLY cinnamon-y, and not thick enough.  It really didn't taste like oh ah jian (forgive me, I don't know ping ying) at all.  Plus, it was 7 whopping bucks.

dan bing (egg pancake) - really eggy, but the bing wasn't crispy enough.  it's hard to mess up dan bing though.

salty soy milk (shian do jiang) - VERY tasty.  It's a small-ish bowl, but for 3 bucks, it's not bad.  Lots of vinegar and pork sung.  Would definitely order again.

pork chop rice - The pork chop was okay (but I'm not a huge fan of pork chop), but the seasoned pork and vegetable on the side (the zho zhau) was REALLY good. 

stewed pig ear and bean curd - this tasted pretty much like you would expect.  Decent flavor, though the bean curd was a bit on the salty side.

They have tons of other breakfast items that we didn't get a chance to try, but will update once we come back.  I would have given this place 4 stars if not for that horrid oyster pancake.  Plus, any place that serves decent taiwanese food in the middle of the desert is alright in my book! :)

My wife and I are foodies and having relocated from HK to here we are in constant search of all of our "favorites" from asia.  Being that we would take food vacations to taipei we walked into Yi Mei with some trepidation.

Now before I continue on, I do want to mention that HK is not actually a great place for taiwanese food (or else we wouldnt go on foodie trips to taipei).

We ordered the spicy beef noodle soup.  Had a little bit of heat but not sweating sort of spicy.  Which was great because it had a great taste that would've been covered up had it been too spicy.  Very nice!  It was also quite big, I am used to the little paper bowls of beef noodle soup in the alleyways of taiwan, not the american sized portions.  Couldnt finish it all and the waitress (the owners grand daughter) was great and brought me 2 containers 1 for the soup the other for the noodles so it wouldnt go all soggy together.  

My wife ordered the steamed pork rice.  I knew it was good as soon as she declared "I'm not sharing!"  Of course she did and it was very good we were impressed. 

My wife had the cold soy milk and enjoyed it I ordered the hot and had to put sugar in it, home made and nice. everything was home made and it was like having a personal taiwanese grandma cooking for us.

Then onto the Xiao Lum Bao.  the filling was good the skin a little thick and not enough "soup" inside the dumpling.  These took awhile but they were by far the best I have had in the USA.  Din Tai Fun sets a very high bar,we have gone to the DTF in taipei, shenzen, hong kong, singapore and jakarta (no pork at DTF in jakarta no pork dumplings suck).

Great food, nice family atmosphere place.  We will be going back anytime we plan on going to the 168 market for shopping.

Dim sum in Vegas, am I right?  But maybe you're a little spooked by other places that have long waits or lousy reputations on yelp. Well open your mind to a slightly different experience: tawainese breakfast! It's slightly different than dim sum but not so different that you'll be confused. There's XLB, there's bao, there's chinese doughnuts, there's all kinds of spicy nom noms, there's something for everyone! Seriously!

We came here on a Sunday morning, hungry. We left the opposite of hungry. The service was friendly if a little slow to get started. We liked the ample parking and the fact that a Chinese tour group showed up right after we did (they ate their breakfast like champions - truly impressive intake) and that we were the only native English speakers there.  Most importantly we liked the food and appreciated the good advice we got from our server. And the bill was reasonable too. :)

Enjoy life. Regret nothing. Eat at Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli. You'll be the champion when you do.

Came here when a Taiwanese friend was in town, because of course I need help ordering. Overall, the food was amazing! But this place is a small, family owned place, that only makes up for the shabby appearance by the quality food. I will say that it gave it an authentic feel - grandpa was sitting at the table next to us packaging freshly roasted peanuts and I'm pretty sure I saw grandma back in the kitchen. Definitely coming back here, I only hope I can replicate the amazing meal I had here without help ordering. But then again, even  the dishes that I'd normally avoid (because I don't know much about authentic Taiwanese cuisine) like the oyster pancake/omelette, were so surprisingly good! My friend lives in DC and kept saying she couldn't believe the authentic dishes they served because she had otherwise only had them when she was actually in Taiwan.

Disappointed.. it seems like soybean milk is diluted by a lot of water as it taste super plain. 
Salty rice roll is just average...maybe I should try another flavor.
Beef roll is the only one I'm satisfied with for this meal. Beef is tender and soaked up tasty flavor. It may taste better if the roll can be a little bit more crispy (not fully crispy)

I cannot stop thinking about their mushroom and pork buns!  They're filled with stuffing and the bun is a soft pillowy exterior.  They have traditional Chinese breakfast and the prices are pretty cheap.  Come here for those buns if for nothing else.

For Las Vegas, this Taiwanese place is decent.  The chicken roll is very authentic, zha jiang mian is tasty, and Taiwanese beef rolls aren't bad.  I wasn't expecting good authentic Taiwanese food in Las Vegas, but this place is decent enough to satiate the Taiwanese cravings!

It's average taiwanese food, but for Vegas standards, it really pretty good.  I had the stinky tofu (not stinky at all), beef stew noodle soup, and oyster egg pancake.  The stinky tofu tastied just like regular fried tofu.  The beef stew noodle soup was delicious, probably the best seller in the store, the oyster egg pancake smelled fishy, not recommended.  

But they also serve soy milk, with pastry, so if you're craving that it's probably a dependable place to go to.

Beware. This place has good food most of the time but the service there has always been terrible. They definitely don't deserve to be tipped. Now they started charging gratuity for everything including even if only one  person. If they want a tip then provide service don't charge someone for providing bad service. Will not be returning. To many others places that serves good food as well as provide outstanding  service.

Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli is my favorite savory dining experience that I had this past weekend. Well, maybe it tied with Trattoria Nakamura Ya...Anyway, this unassuming spot deserves more than its 3.5 star average.

If you're craving a big breakfast, then Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli provides the perfect alternative to eggs, bacon, and pancakes. And it also offers an attractive and arguably superior alternative to dim sum (while I enjoy dim sum, most dim sum restaurants are guilty of making their small plates way too salty, maybe on purpose...).

Just like mentioned in the name, Yi Mei Champion is a Taiwanese deli that provides homey, comforting, perfectly cooked dishes. Honestly, this was the Taiwanese dining experience that I so wanted when I visited in Taipei but didn't get. Casual restaurants are fine by me, actually preferred, but many restaurants that I encountered in the different districts of Taipei seemed to have really questionable sanitation practices, making me nervous to try much. I feel like such a wimp, but that's the truth. Yi Mei is a simple restaurant, but it seemed pretty clean. All our silverware and plates were spotless.

But more importantly, Yi Mei Champion's food is so good. The oyster omelet was on point. It wasn't overly sauced and had lots of oysters. The Chinese donuts for dipping in soups and salty soy bean milk was wonderful--crispy on the outside and hollow on the inside. We tried a few items we'd never had before, like their egg and radish cake. Superlative menu item. It's so delicious, something you must order. We also had something similar to a pork bun or bao, except it was filled with veggies, very flavorful. Their salty soy bean milk is really tasty, too, but it comes with pork floss. Good to know if you don't eat meat. Hubby also sampled pork sticky rice wrapped in a banana leaf, which was another win. Lastly, try their refreshing iced tea from the fridge.

I really love this place. I thought service was polite and prompt, though not chatty. Service was definitely not bad, contrary to what has been described in other reviews. I would highly recommend Yi Mei for an early morning bite, whether a substantial meal or something more akin to a snack. Everything we tried was delicious.
The yummy breakfast brought back my childhood memory. I wished to order the entire menu. Owner learned that we came from NJ and treated us ???? How wonderful to start the day!

Not the place to go if you are looking for great dinning experience, but if you want delicious food for cheap, this is the place! All their tables are large fitted for family so no worries if you have a big group. 

Our orders were taken quickly, water was brought out as soon as we asked for it, and food came out within minutes! Their minced pork over rice was so good! Great flavors and great portion, came out super quick...can be a little greasy but that is what makes it so good!

The pork chop rice was HUGE! Came with minced pork also, veggies and was big enough for two to share. The beef roll was also good, came with pickled cucumbers and fermented cabbage that was similar to kim-chi. 

I didn't really care for the oyster omelet with the sauce on top, their soup dumpling was decent, juicy but the lacked in flavor a little. 

Overall i will definitely come back for the rice and I really want to try their breakfast items. We used to always go to this other place for Taiwanese style breakfast, although that place was good they get really busy and food takes awhile. Looking forward to trying the breakfast menu here.

Authentic Taiwanese place where the food is legit, and my mom and her friends love to come here often when in Vegas.  Their strong suit is Taiwanese/Chinese brunch dishes, and it's very affordably priced (for Vegas) with good portions.  

I really liked the pork and chive dumplings (fresh and juicy, perfect) and pan-fried scallion pancake (definitely one of the better ones I've had). Service at this unassuming place is friendly too.
The service here is non existent and rude. We can't speak for the food as we ended up leaving. If you come here, it's better to order takeout or else you will be waiting forever.

Foods good, prices are good, but damn, that wait and service!

We were promptly seated but had to wait over 10 minutes for someone to take our order!

we got the salted rice rolls, juicy pork dumplings, and minced pork rice. The salted rice roll was good, the juicy pork dumplings fell apart, and the minced pork rice was tons of rice with just a little bit of minced pork. 

Im not sure if we'll be back but it was cheaper than eating on the strip, that's for sure!

Not bad for a "Taiwan Deli" in Las Vegas...being from Southern California it's harder to compare these restaurants in Vegas to the quality of the ones in LA.

The Green Onion Pancake had no flavor because they didn't put much salt in it but it was also not as greasy as most places which was kinda good.

Plenty of dishes to choose from I got my standard chicken and rice...but it just wasn't the same as other restaurants.

Kinda pricey - almost $40 (whaaaattt) for Taiwanese breakfast .  i was feeling crappy and wanted some comfort food. 2 older ladies were nice and auntie-like (you asians know what i mean). she handed us paper breakfast menus, i asked if they had food other than breakfast (it was 9:30am), she went and got the regular menu and said noodles were available and recomemded the taiwanese beef noodle soup.

1. beef roll: not good, the bing was dry, the beef was so-so
2. beef noodle soup: really good, large chunks of beef and beef tendon, delicious homestyle noodles. main reason this place was 1star more than a "meh ive had better"
3. soybean milk: hot or cold, served in a bowl like it should be, so-so, not worth the price tag
4. xiao long bao: surprisingly good, lots of soup, meat filling was flavorful
5. cold pig ear appetizer: sold per little clear container (like if you were to buy macaroni salad at a deli) and pretty good, pricey but this dish always is.
6. chive he-zi (turnover/pocket): meh

next time id just come and share a bowl of the beef noodle soup... and use the money i saved to try other delicious things in the area
Finally found the place, love there spicy beef tendon soup, but they discontinued their stinky tofu!! Bring it back!! Lol

Went there for Taiwanese style breakfast with high hopes, ordered some usual brekkie items such as pancake and donut, beef roll, savory soy milk, and rice roll. The flavors were right on, but the restaurant didn't seem to care enough to make the dishes more enjoyable; the soy milk was lukewarm, the beef roll was dry from sitting out for too long, and the donut was way too greasy. This place could have easily been much better, they just didn't care.

Hello 626. I missed you, my Taiwanese breakfast. I sat down alone, because my Taiwanese friend is never available, and ordered my favorite breakfast: an order of sugar spiked soy milk, fan tuan (salty,) beef roll, and an order of juicy steamed juicy pork dumplings. I don't eat this much, so I save the rest for later. 
This place is always serving tasty and freshly made food. The service is good and the location is perfect. The prices were about the same as Cali's branch. It was all about $22.

Authentic Taiwanese food. Every bite feels like it was made by mom (hopefully your mom was a great cook). My friend's mom, who is Taiwanese, buys in bulk here and takes it back to her state!

Location: Chinatown, plenty of parking in the plaza

Ambiance: Mom and Pop. Friendly owner and chef! Good for groups/family. 

Food: 
1. Spicy beef noodle soup -- 5 stars 
They make their own noodles and the consistency is chewy and soft. These noodles soak up the soup without losing their texture. 
2. Scallion pancake -- 5 stars
Not doughy at all! Crispy!
3. Tea eggs -- 4 stars
Take it to go and eat it the next day for breakfast!
4. Soup dumplings -- 4 stars
The wrapper is a bit thick. The pork and veggie filling is tasty!

Price: For all this food, we had plenty of left overs for 2. About $13/person. 

I don't think they have an alcohol license, but if you ask them politely they are open to BYOB.

If you try this place out you might enjoy some interesting cheap-ish food, but the overall experience will be very confusing and somewhat unpleasant feeling.

We dropped by for lunch on an early Saturday afternoon. It got a little busy right after we arrived which might've contributed to the strange time we experienced there.

We ordered a few dishes to start with. We wanted some other things as well, but no one came back to take our additional orders. I tried to get someone's attention, but they were all running around like chickens with their heads cut off. Our dishes were delivered by a male server who would drop the dish off, mention what it is and then immediately run off. Wrong dishes were delivered to our table a couple of times.

Their menu is very difficult to follow if you don't already know what you want. The pictures on Yelp are very useful for figuring out what some of the dishes are.

If you don't mind not knowing what you are ordering and if you don't mind servers that have no time to talk to you about anything, then you might have an okay time here. Otherwise, the dining experience is so confusing we won't be going back.

I was fortunate to be introduced to this place by a friend (who actually was visting Las Vegas). Definitely a place that I know frequent when I am craving true Taiwanese breakfast food or spicy beef noodle soup. And every time I do check in here, my friend from LA is jealous!

I havent had that many things on the menu here, but thats only because I tend to order the same thing! For $2.25 you can get the salty rice rolls (with preserved pork inside). These things are so good and they are made fresh to order! The other thing I always get is the spicy beef noodle soup with tendon. This rivals many of the places I go to in LA and the portion is actually bigger here. Definitely some comfort food, especially after a long night of drinking.

If you are craving some authentic Taiwanese food, this is the place to be!

Four of us from the SF/LA area tried the Taiwanese breakfast at this hole-in-the-wall.

Recommend:  Spicy beef soup with tendon, Taiwan sweet spicy cabbage, tendon brisket tofu, beef sandwich.

Okay:  Green onion pancake with egg, salty rice roll (fan tuan), pot stickers.

Not so great:  Sweet soy milk (not at all sweet), Chinese donut (not crispy).

I had the fan tuan (rice ball) and love it! The fried Chinese "donut" was crispy and fragrant. They don't skimp on the pork floss and the rice was just the right texture, not too hard, but solid enough to maintain structural integrity and offering the perfect level of chewiness. The fan tuan here was WAY better than the one from their LA store.

I also had the beef shao bing (sandwich-like thing). I was caught off guard that it came cold. I mean, I get that it's prepared but couldn't they at least serve it lukewarm? or room temp? I couldn't eat it cold so I had the waitress reheat it for me. 

After the reheating, it was pretty good, but but blow-my-mind spectacular. The dough was crispy and the beef was okay. 

The douhua (soy...jelly?) was very refreshing. I love that it was not too sweet and you can add sugar to your liking.

Get the fan tuan.

I love radish cake with egg, and they do not disappoint here. Beautifully crunchy on the outside, wonderfully creamy on the inside... goes well with some hot soy milk, sweetened with table sugar.  Also recommend their champion rice roll with spicy pickles. It's not too hot, just sour crunch with heat tempered with sweet pork fung.
Love their breakfast foods, but the servers were always hurried and not patient when you have questions. Go there for food but don't expect too much from the service.

This review is only for the rice balls (glutinous rice wrapped with shredded pork, fried dough, picked vegetables) - generous size, plenty of fillings, satisfied my cravings for rice ball.  Will return when in the area.

I went to this restaurant on 12/26/2016. It was a horrible experience. Bad service. Poor food quality with expensive price. Dishonest! Tips were already added but there's still a blank field for tips on credit card check.

???36????????42????????????????10%????????????????42???? amount????? tips ?? total ??????????????????????????
???????????????????????

We went to this restaurant during a visit from San Diego. My friend recommended we should try here.
She was right. They had best spicy beef noodle soup, steam bun.... The spicy beef noodle soup was so good that I felt at home in Taiwan. The mixed vegetable and meat buns were so fresh and delicious . You definitely should not miss here when you come to vegas and crave for really good Taiwanese food.

The service was great, the owner treat you like family, we ordered some steam buns to go to give to our friends in San Diego, she even gave us some fee items into our take out order. So kind of her.

??????????????????????????????????????????????????....?????????????????
Good over all, but don't expect polite or good service.. Food is authentic  Taiwanese.. Really miss the flavors of these dishes.  Definitely a good fine.

I don't understand the low ratings.  If I lived in Vegas, I would be here every week.  Everyone was really nice to us when we were there. Taiwanese street food is not supposed to be super new and shiny and I guess the decor might put some people off. But their breakfast rice rolls are super authentic and delicious. I love how crunchy the Chinese donuts are and how well cooked the glutinous rice is.  It tastes good even when it is cold.  We tried both the Champion and Yi Mei rice rolls.  Both were super good.  We were lucky enough to buy their freshly made mochi. We tried all three flavors and loved all of them.  My personal favorite is the red bean but my husband said the peanut and sesame mochi were delicious too.

Honestly, this place was great! As I entered Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli, it was crowded so I assumed it was good. When we got seated we waited for about 20 minutes before the waiter got to us. When we ordered food, the waiter cut us off and went to the kitchen. Me and my friends were not finished yet. People got their food before us and my friends got their Waters before I did. Later our food came. It was DELICIOUS but we still had to order the rest of the order that we didn't get to tell the waiter. 5 minutes later he got to us. The food was great (again). After we were done we paid and tipped them and then were on our way back to our hotel. Personally it was good but the service was just a tiny bit slow. Thank you!

found this place on yelp on my recent vacation to vegas... i was excited with the notion of a taiwanese breakfast place, but honestly, the food was ok, but the service was great! i love their breakfast tea!

Taiwanese style breakfast in Vegas what else can you expect?  A piece of my hometown food at way cheaper than tourist food on the stripe?! I take two!!

Came here on the most crowded days- Christmas weekend, ladies in the house were in commend and obviously in good mood.  Saw them giving kids rice cracker cookies, one big package per child- well Merry Christmas and here is when you say the reason you love Taiwanese people:). 

Packed house and yet very efficient.  One tradition about Chinese dinning is that you need to be able to stand other guests staring at you and giving you a very clear hint of hurry up that we want to sit down look.  Don't be offended, that's part of the culture.  You gotta not be shy and be flexible in the seating, that could range from share table to servers bussing your table so quickly that you get that you can't hang out and take your time.  In our case, we are two people so the best chance to grab a quick bite is to let them know we are willing to share table.  Both days we waited for less than 5 minutes.  Oh, and politeness always work in your favor, I smile and wish them Merry Christmas, got the tables ahead of whole grumpy bunch who complaint that they waited 30 minutes.  

We order all the vegetarian spread, ranging from soy milk (comes plain, sugar bottle on the table for customized sweetness), Chinese donut ???classic rice ball, vege bun, egg pancake, second day I had porridge with some classic tapas like fermented tofu cube and cucumber salad.  Hit the spot, nothing extraordinary but everything nostalgic.  I can't really complaint when my homies open the doors at 7am to serve these massive crazy amount of hungry people.  I am grateful for these hard working servers and cooks and looking forward for this classic ritual again next time when I am in Vegas!
Got the salty tofu and Chinese donut to go. Food was good and Service was good too. Got my food within 10 minutes. Will go back again if I'm craving Taiwanese breakfast.

New location is over on Spring Mt and Arville. It sits right behind the AM/PM. Straight to the point kind of food. Good price and good portions. A must is: Spicy Beef Noodles (and tendon optional, but recommended), Crispy roll w/pork and also the mushroom and pork bun. These are my top 3 recommendation for first timers. Service speed depends on how packed the place is. I'm usually in and out in about 15 minutes or less. It's a great hidden gem, that us locals go to. And the noodles are as homemade as you can get.

Worst service and restaurant management. I have been here many times. The food was ok, but the reason I giving one star here is they said they can't make any food right now, because they got a 300 order of lunch box. I can't even get an egg in my steam bread. 

If you take the order that beyond your ability, you know you will get negative customers review like i did.

Authentic Taiwanese food.  Source: me, a Taiwanese.  Also the management, who are Taiwanese.

Friendliest people working here, I came here to eat while I was house-hunting and was welcomed like family.  

They close whenever they run out of food for the day, so if you go at 3pm don't be upset if they're closed.  Closing varies slightly.

They're located in the inner corner of a little strip mall, not directly on the road.  Chinese & English menu, breakfast is served all day (not just 7-9am or so).

I am so happy to have found my Taiwanese eatery here in Vegas, feels like home again.  Such good food.

We ( My date and I ) checked out this newly opened Taiwanese Deli place that's next to Lelysee Bakery and near 168 Market.

Reminds me of Tea Planet without the booth seats and colorful interior. They have some snacks and health products for sale that you can browse through if you like..

They have a self serve utensils and water dispenser if you need an extra bowl or cup to share food or just to drink plain water.

We ordered the Chrysanthemum Tea, which was delightfully refreshing to taste. I could drink 10 of these if there were refills.. but that's just wishful thinking. This is my all time summer drink to cool my body when I feel like I'm about to experience heat exhaustion... it works instantly and you literally feel relieved.. even to say... Aaaaaaaaaaah!!

For dinner, we ordered two most popular Taiwanese dishes:

Spicy Beef Noodle (Soup) - Surprised it wasn't overpowering with the spices that I thought it would have. It was actually just right in giving it a kick each time you took a sip. I actually really enjoyed this broth. I loved the noodles! It had a great texture as if it was homemade. Thicker than fettuccine noodles, but thinner width-wise. It was like udon noodles texture, but half its size... absolutely enjoyed every bite. The beef was like stew meat that is cooked for many hours... unfortunately I had to minus a star for the fact that some of the chunks of meat ( the ends/corners of it ) were quite tough to chew upon. And for that reason, I couldn't even eat the remainder of the beef chunks, but I did finish all the noodles, sliced green cabbage, and some kind of pickled shredded mustard green.

Rice with Pork Chop - It also came with a boiled egg, steam greens, and ground pork. The coating is somewhat similar to katsu style, but this batter they dip the pork chop into and deep fry is on point! It had a light, airy crispy crunch on the outside.. which was my favorite!!! * My eyes lit up like Christmas lights in full blast from biting into a piece. Very tasty and satisfied all my taste buds. Even the meat was tender and juicy.  Bravo!! Bravooooo!!! I definitely recommend this dish if you love meat and deep fried food. It really hits the spot indefinitely :)

They also open at 7a.m.- 11:30a.m. for breakfast, which I heard was incredibly cheap, but good. Service was quick, but not much smiles... At least my tummy was smiling and it put me in a great mood. Hey I'm an emotional eater... What? *Ladeedadee skipping away.....

We loved it so much so we went again on the second day. However, the server on the second day was having bad attitude on us because she didn't want us to pay separately with credit card when we didn't reach the credit card  pay limit. I love this place. I had spicy beef soup, pork & leek dumplings and spicy peanut noodles. Everything was great but the spicy peanut noodles seem to miss something and I couldn't pin point it, so I just added hot chili sauce. The whole meal was just $23 not including tip. The one person staff was friendly but that is all the positive that i can say about it.  

We had the hot soybean milk and it was the worst we have ever tried.  They did not filter the soybeans out of it and there was grinded up soybean gunk and slime in our bowls and it clung to our spoons.  The aftertaste was even worse.  

The selections for other breakfast foods were not as expected for chinese breakfast places.  We wanted a single order of red bean bun, and found out that we had to order a min of 6 at $5.99 total.  Glad we did not order that b/c if it tasted anything like the soybean milk, we would have been highly disappointed.  

we will not be going back.

I had a craving for some Taiwanese food and after checking yelp Yi Mei Champion Deli came up. It's a small funky restaurant with a very confusing ordering and table service system. There is a counter with a menu board but, there is a full menu with table service. After figuring it out, we ordered the beef noodle soup, fried stinky tofu, and squid pottage. 

The sticky tofu was good, nice portions and came out hot tasty.

The Squid Pottage was OK, the soup was authentic tasting but the squid was kinda weird in texture.

The beef noodle soup was not very good at all. It lacked the spicy bean paste flavor and was watery salty soy sauce based. The noodles were OK. We didn't mind it being spicy but warning to people who don't like spicy food the regular beef noodle soup is very spicy.

Service was good. Plenty of Parking.

Sure, I love their one-of-a-kind salty soy milk and egg-wrapped fried bread, but what struck me are the values that the deli owners & employees strive to uphold. A sign in Chinese read the following: 

"However frustrated you are, don't forget to smile.
However impatient you are, don't forget to be polite.
However difficult, don't forget to persevere.
However tired you are, don't forget to take care of yourself."

Restaurants often deliver great food, but never have I been to one that has also delivered words of wisdom. Thanks for the reminder, Yi Mei Deli!

Two visits, one on 12/18/16 and one on 12/20/16:

This place was recommended to me by Taiwanese restaurant owners who used to live in Vegas and have since relocated to New Mexico to open up Chinese and Taiwanese places in Santa Fe and Albuquerque near me.

Delicious and authentic with a good menu selection. The first time here I got the green onion pancake with egg, jook, and three cup chicken over rice. It also comes with a little bit of vegetables and an egg. The second time I got the green onion pancake and an order of fried rice noodles with meat sauce and egg. My mom tried the rice noodles and approved.

Only reason I can't give it five stars is because the food is too salty. A solid place overall.

Located at the corner of S. Jones and Spring Mountain near the 168 Market, this small humble eatery provides a comprehensive array of Taiwanese breakfast items that elicit childhood nostalgia for many 1st generation Taiwanese/Chinese folks and are definitely on the must-eat list for those of us second-generation folks who have been fortunate to have made a pilgrimmage back to Taiwan (or as I like to call it, Foodie Island).  

Soybean milk-  this is not the chalky stuff that you find in your supermarket that adds a nice dimension to your latte or cereal, this is enjoyed straight up either as a sweetened cold/hot beverage or in a savory form where a shot of vinegar and soy triggers a reaction so that the soymilk takes on a creamy custardization accented by little bits of green onion and pickled veggies.  For those with discernible palates, I've been informed by reputable sources that the soybean milk across the street at China Mama is superior.

Rice Ball (Fan Twan)- a classic item my parents used to grab on the go while heading to school, don't be fooled by the simple name.  This is steamed sticky rice enclosing a savory deep fried chinese doughnut and pork sung.  The ratio of the rice and filling is perfect and it's as classic a combination as pb and j.

Temple meatball (Ba Wan)-  not sure if there are any other places in town that offer this, and fortunately they make a wonderful version of this popular street food item.    Finely chopped mushrooms, bamboo, and stir-fried pork encased by a glutinous tapioca flour bun and bathed in a thick orange sweet savory sauce that has an additional note similar to cinnamon/star anise, this one will flood your head with umami and makes me think if boba and dim sum were to conceive a rockstar child, this would be it.

Spicy Beef Noodle soup-   Served piping hot and can easily feed 2 or more, the meat is impeccably braised and comes with garnishes of pickled mustard greens, cilantro, scallions, and bok choy.  Detractors might say it is on the oily side and is way spicy (in which case the version at Noodle Pot may be closer to your liking), otherwise this one punches you in the face and is not shy on flavor in the best way possible.

Leek Pancake- A deep-fried empanada filled with garlic chives, scrambled egg, tofu, and mung bean noodles, this is a tasty rendition if you really like garlic chives.

Items that have room for improvement include the savory chinese doughnuts (yiotiao) and the sesame bun (sao bing) which I found to be a tad bit on the dry side, and the hunk of pork in the pork bun (gua bao) is also a bit oversized and lacking unctuousness (Sheridan Su does a better rendition at Great Bao which is now Fat Choy).  Looking forward to trying the pork chop with rice, sweet tofu custard (do hua), and the lotus wrapped tamales (taiwanese and shanghainese varieties available) on future visits. 

Not sure if this is an outpost of Yi Mei Deli Co. in Rowland Heights, CA (the fonts on the food signs look similar), but if you're expecting the same level of quality, it may come up short since they set the bar extremely high, otherwise it's a great primer on Taiwanese cuisine for the uninitiated.  Unbelievable value for your wallet but don't forget cash if you're spending under $10 and they accept visa/mastercard but no amex.

The food tasted ok. I've ordered the spicy beef noodle and the oyster pancake, wasn't impressed with neither. I also found a HAIR in my noodle, gross. 
Also, if you want water, you have to get it yourself in the water station, wtf??? Should I also go into the kitchen and get the food myself???

Perfect Chinese food. Really, regardless of the Yelp rating which is mainly resulted from their tricks in billing, have to say the food is excellent. And it is not expensive at all. 

??????

Food is very delicious and authentic. However, like other reviewers mentioned, service is non existent here. We had the salty rice roll and egg pancake with Chinese donut, both are great. If the wait time isn't so long and service better, we'll definitely come back. As is, we'll have to think about it.

Came here for a quick breakfast before a day of skiing, and it was great that this place is open at 7am! (So that we could make it to the slopes by 9) Service was quick and the menu was pretty extensive.

We had an assortment of the standard Chinese breakfast fare (although there were a few menu items that were unavailable). The you tiao were alright, but I really liked their green onion pancake! Overall a great place to grab some authentic Chinese breakfast!

Delicious.  I bet the 3-star rating is due to the extreme authenticity. (Not a lot of food descriptions).

Rice roll with pickled mustard greens, salted soybean, and green onion pancake were my favorites.

Went to the old address thinking it was in the 626 market plaza but its not! They have moved so make sure you have the right one down. I've never been to the old restaurant but the new location is pretty big. Lots of large tables. They have a display case of steamed buns in the front near the register. I've been craving steamed buns for a few months but haven't been able to find a good place in LV. I wanted plain steamed buns and Yi Mei carries small ones and super big ones at reasonable prices. They also have pork and vegetable ones as well. 

My friends and I ordered the beef noodle soup, but the broth was clear. It wasn't what I was expecting... I should have ordered the spicy beef noodle soup instead. I felt the broth was a bit on the bland side. 

We also ordered the beef rolls, which were just ok. It was lacking sauce so it was also a bit bland IMO. I probably will be back to order steamed buns to go but will skip on everything else.

Got the XLB, potstickers, pork bun, chive pancakes, and soy milk. Only the XLB and the potstickers were alright, the rest just didn't suit me and my family's tastes. The soy milk was especially watered down.

***** Worst Beef Noodle Soup ***** 

The instant beef noodle soup (Nissin- I believe) is better.  Seriously, go put that in the microwave and it'll be better.  And trust me, I am a snob.  I grew up in a town with alot of Taiwanese people.

I'll give it 2 stars because the niu rou xiao bing (don't know the english name) but it' s like a flaky pastry with beef inside is good.  

There's some decent stuff here and I guess since there's not a plethora of Taiwanese options, I can see why people are reviewing higher.

Worst place ever, we been here for 20minutes for our food, the owner said that this is not fastfood place, everyone else came after us already got there food, the servers didn't even tell us that we needed to wait for a bowl of noodle.  It a dry place too.

Just arrived in Las Vegas and the first thing to do is to..... eat Taiwanese food! 

Anyways, this is a small hole in the wall restaurant in Vegas' Chinatown. Not too clean. Service is ok. Looks like they have a steady stream of customers. 

We wanted the minced pork with noodles and was told there were no more noodles for that dish left. I guess they sell out by the afternoon? The thing is that they can buy it at the 99 Ranch Market almost right next door. We settled for the minced pork with rice. 

We also ordered two different types of noodle bowls- the noodles with the dumplings and thin noodles.

The food overall was not too bad. 

The portions were huge; we couldn't finish everything. The prices were cheap compared to Southern California.

I was surprised to see only 3.5 stars for this place after eating here. When you walk into a small taiwanese restaurant and you see taiwanese people eating there, you've gotta know something is up.

This place has all your standard taiwanese fare such as fan tuan (stick rice rolls with chinese donut and dried pork inside), oyster pancake (tad bit thick and consistency of the sauce wasn't as great), taiwanese beef noodle soup, green onion pancakes with egg, soy milk (sweet and salty) etc. etc.

Everything was spot on delicious, although the only dish i wouldn't "recommend" would be the oyster pancake. Although it was still good, it wasn't great by any means. The waitstaff was helpful and treated us well! I would definitely return here if I'm off the strip searching for some good ol fashioned taiwanese brunch!

Dont think I would be back. Not very authentic Taiwanese food.
